Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Ayla Susan Pamukcu of Vanderbilt University to conduct a research project, entitled "How long did it take to develop the giant magma bodies that resulted in the Oruanui and Whakamaru supereruptions?" during the summer of 2012 at University of Canterbury in Christchurch, New Zealand. The host scientist is Dr. Darren Gravley.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to develop a greater understanding of the timescales over which giant magma bodies persist in the Earth's crust prior to eruption, through the study of textures (sizes, shapes) and compositions of crystals, bubbles, and glass. Such results can aid in the development of volcanic hazards programs. In addition, this work serves to further develop analytical techniques in the fields of igneous petrology and volcanology, such as conventional, differential absorption, and propagation phase-contrast x-ray tomography and cathodoluminescence.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supereruptions are rare eruptions that expel large volumes (>450 km3) of material, often in a relatively short period of time (days to months). Such large eruptions have the potential to wreak havoc on the Earth and pose great risks to humanity. As a result, it is important to understand the timescales over which the giant magma bodies that result in supereruptions develop and erupt. The goal of this project is to better understand these timescales.

For this work we are studying textures (shapes, sizes, positions) of crystals and melt inclusions in crystals, as well as the compositions of crystals, to determine the durations over which these magma bodies developed prior to erupting. We are studying two supereruptions (Oruanui Tuff, Whakamaru Group Ignimbrites) that occurred in the Taupo Volcanic Zone (New Zealand), an area that has been the source of numerous large eruptions and continues to be volcanically active. Current work has focused on textures of melt inclusions in crystals. We have employed synchrotron-based x-ray tomography for this work, and we have developed a new method for imaging these inclusions: propagation phase-contrast x-ray tomography. This method is non-destructive and allows us to study inclusions in situ and in three dimensions. In processing these images we determine size, shape, and position of melt inclusions in a crystal, which we use to calculate residence times of the crystals and, in turn, the timescales over which the magma body evolved. Preliminary results from melt inclusions in quartz crystals from the Oruanui Tuff suggests the Oruanui magma body developed over very short timescales 10s-1000s of years prior to erupting.
